dict.string:
PROSE FICTION:ÊThis passage is excerpted fromÊThe Promise(1969) by Chaim Potok.

It was cold and an icy wind that blewalong Broadway and up through the narrowside street where Danny lived, a fierce windthat came off the river, which I could not see
5 for the darkness. The house was small, threestories, red brick, and old, very old. Fiveworn, stone stairs, a badly fitting woodendoor, a tiny overheated foyer withmailboxes, buttons, and nameplates.ÊI
10 pressed the button over the name Saunders.ÊThere was a loud answering buzz.ÊI pushedÊopen the heavy inner door and started up theÊsteep, carpeted, narrow staircase.ÊThe doorÊclosed with a loud click.ÊIt was a little
15 before eight o'clock.ÊSomeone inside theÊhouse was frying bacon.ÊThe staircase wasÊpoorly lighted; the carpet was worn.ÊIt wasÊa long climb up to the third floor.ÊDanny was waiting for me in his
20 doorway.ÊHe had on a dark woolen sweaterÊand dark trousers.ÊThere was a skullcap onÊhis head.ÊHis face was pale and he blinkedÊat me wearily from behind his black shell-Êrimmed glasses.
25 "How are you, Danny?ÊHow areÊyou really?"Ê"Tired."Ê"You're always tired.ÊWhenever IÊsee you you're tired."
30 "It's the occupational disease ofÊgraduate school."Ê"How is Rachel?"Ê"Rachel is fine."ÊHe sat down on the chair in front of
35 the desk and did not look at me.Ê"Tell me about Michael," I said.ÊHe picked up his coffee cup, sippedÊsome coffee, and put it back down on theÊdesk.
40 "Michael is very sick."Ê"Thanks.ÊNow tell me somethingÊabout Michael I don't already know."Ê"You're angry," he said.Ê"I can'tÊtalk to you when you're angry."
45 "Tell me about Michael," I saidÊquietly.Ê"What does he do?"Ê"He doesn't do anything.ÊHe comesÊinto a therapy session and just sits there.ÊOon't cooperate at all."Ê"Are you taking over the therapy?"Ê"Yes.ÊThey're willing to try almostÊanything now.ÊIt's very serious withÊMichael."
55 I found I could not stop thinkingÊabout Michael.ÊThere was the lake againÊand Michael's thin body near the centerÊboard of the sailfish and the gusting windsÊand the clouds scudding smoothly across the
60 sky.Ê"There have been fist fights.ÊBetween Michael and some of the otherÊboys."Ê"Fist fights," I said.ÊI could not
65 imagine Michael in a fist fight.Ê"He kicked a boy in the groin.ÊDuring a lunch hour.ÊHe pushed him out ofÊthe chair and kicked him".Ê"How much time do you have?"
70 "A month.ÊTwo months.ÊIt dependsÊon whether there's any kind of progress".Ê"What if there's no progress,ÊDanny?"ÊHe glanced down at his desk and
75 said nothing.Ê"Will he have to beÊinstitutionalized?"ÊI said.ÊHe did not say anything.Ê"My God," I said.Ê"My God....All
80 because of a stupid carnival."ÊHe looked at me.Ê"Michael was sickÊlong before that carnival.ÊCrooks atÊcarnivals don't make people sick.ÊYou haveÊto be sick already to be affected that way.
85 "We had a beautiful time on thatÊlake.ÊHe liked to read clouds.ÊDid I tell youÊabout that?ÊHe reads clouds."Ê"You told me."ÊI finished the coffee.Ê"The summer
90 seems very far away."ÊHe was quiet.Ê"It is far away," I said.ÊI put theÊempty coffee cup on the floor and leanedÊback against the wall and closed my eyes.ÊI
95 could not stop thinking aboutÊMichael....There was the cove and theÊsmooth shallow water with the tall trees ofÊthe shoreline breaking the force of the windÊand Michael lying on his back reading the
100 clouds.ÊThere was the cove and the birdsÊÊhigh overhead and the clouds white againstÊÊthe deep blue of the sky and the whisper ofÊÊthe wind through the trees, a loudÊÊwhisper...and I saw Michael standing up in
105 the roller coaster, his face to the wind...andÊÊthe sensation of dropping into the night.

When the author says, ÒWe had a beautiful time on that lakeÓ (lines 85-86), he is referring to:
he finds the speakerÕs manner intrusive and irritating.
his eyes hurt from reading in the poorly lit room.
he feels uncomfortable with the topic of their conversation.
he is overtired from his work with Michael.

PROSE FICTION:ÊThis passage is excerpted fromÊThe Promise(1969) by Chaim Potok.

It was cold and an icy wind that blewalong Broadway and up through the narrowside street where Danny lived, a fierce windthat came off the river, which I could not see
5 for the darkness. The house was small, threestories, red brick, and old, very old. Fiveworn, stone stairs, a badly fitting woodendoor, a tiny overheated foyer withmailboxes, buttons, and nameplates.ÊI
10 pressed the button over the name Saunders.ÊThere was a loud answering buzz.ÊI pushedÊopen the heavy inner door and started up theÊsteep, carpeted, narrow staircase.ÊThe doorÊclosed with a loud click.ÊIt was a little
15 before eight o'clock.ÊSomeone inside theÊhouse was frying bacon.ÊThe staircase wasÊpoorly lighted; the carpet was worn.ÊIt wasÊa long climb up to the third floor.ÊDanny was waiting for me in his
20 doorway.ÊHe had on a dark woolen sweaterÊand dark trousers.ÊThere was a skullcap onÊhis head.ÊHis face was pale and he blinkedÊat me wearily from behind his black shell-Êrimmed glasses.
25 "How are you, Danny?ÊHow areÊyou really?"Ê"Tired."Ê"You're always tired.ÊWhenever IÊsee you you're tired."
30 "It's the occupational disease ofÊgraduate school."Ê"How is Rachel?"Ê"Rachel is fine."ÊHe sat down on the chair in front of
35 the desk and did not look at me.Ê"Tell me about Michael," I said.ÊHe picked up his coffee cup, sippedÊsome coffee, and put it back down on theÊdesk.
40 "Michael is very sick."Ê"Thanks.ÊNow tell me somethingÊabout Michael I don't already know."Ê"You're angry," he said.Ê"I can'tÊtalk to you when you're angry."
45 "Tell me about Michael," I saidÊquietly.Ê"What does he do?"Ê"He doesn't do anything.ÊHe comesÊinto a therapy session and just sits there.ÊOr he spouts dreams and fantasies that are
50 absolute lies.ÊHe won't cooperate at all."Ê"Are you taking over the therapy?"Ê"Yes.ÊThey're willing to try almostÊanything now.ÊIt's very serious withÊMichael."
55 I found I could not stop thinkingÊabout Michael.ÊThere was the lake againÊand Michael's thin body near the centerÊboard of the sailfish and the gusting windsÊand the clouds scudding smoothly across the
60 sky.Ê"There have been fist fights.ÊBetween Michael and some of the otherÊboys."Ê"Fist fights," I said.ÊI could not
65 imagine Michael in a fist fight.Ê"He kicked a boy in the groin.ÊDuring a lunch hour.ÊHe pushed him out ofÊthe chair and kicked him".Ê"How much time do you have?"
70 "A month.ÊTwo months.ÊIt dependsÊon whether there's any kind of progress".Ê"What if there's no progress,ÊDanny?"ÊHe glanced down at his desk and
75 said nothing.Ê"Will he have to beÊinstitutionalized?"ÊI said.ÊHe did not say anything.Ê"My God," I said.Ê"My God....All
80 because of a stupid carnival."ÊHe looked at me.Ê"Michael was sickÊlong before that carnival.ÊCrooks atÊcarnivals don't make people sick.ÊYou haveÊto be sick already to be affected that way.
85 "We had a beautiful time on thatÊlake.ÊHe liked to read clouds.ÊDid I tell youÊabout that?ÊHe reads clouds."Ê"You told me."ÊI finished the coffee.Ê"The summer
90 seems very far away."ÊHe was quiet.Ê"It is far away," I said.ÊI put theÊempty coffee cup on the floor and leanedÊback against the wall and closed my eyes.ÊI
95 could not stop thinking aboutÊMichael....There was the cove and theÊsmooth shallow water with the tall trees ofÊthe shoreline breaking the force of the windÊand Michael lying on his back reading the
100 clouds.ÊThere was the cove and the birdsÊÊhigh overhead and the clouds white againstÊÊthe deep blue of the sky and the whisper ofÊÊthe wind through the trees, a loudÊÊwhisper...and I saw Michael standing up in
105 the roller coaster, his face to the wind...andÊÊthe sensation of dropping into the night.

Danny avoids looking at the speaker because:

80 because of a stupid carnival."ÊHe looked at me.Ê"Michael was sickÊlong before that carnival.ÊCrooks atÊcarnivals don't make people sick.ÊYou haveÊto be sick already to be affected that way.

90 seems very far away."ÊHe was quiet.Ê"It is far away," I said.ÊI put theÊempty coffee cup on the floor and leanedÊback against the wall and closed my eyes.ÊI
95 could not stop thinking aboutÊMichael....There was the cove and theÊsmooth shallow water with the tall trees ofÊthe shoreline breaking the force of the windÊand Michael lying on his back reading the
100 clouds.ÊThere was the cove and the birdsÊÊhigh overhead and the clouds white againstÊÊthe deep blue of the sky and the whisper ofÊÊthe wind through the trees, a loudÊÊwhisper...and I saw Michael standing up in
105 the roller coaster, his face to the wind...andÊÊthe sensation of dropping into the night.

Images of the summer at the lake appear in the passage in order to suggest:
The speaker took Michael to the lake.
Michael encountered a crook at a carnival.
Danny has been asked to take over MichaelÕs therapy.

What has happened since the last time the speaker spoke to Danny?
Michael is uncooperative with his therapists.
Michael does not behave inappropriately in therapy.
Michael does not interact with his peers.
Michael has been wrongly accused of antisocial behavior.

Which of the following best expresses DannyÕs meaning when he says that ÒHe doesnÕt do anything.Ó (line 47).
how long Danny will be allowed to continue working with Michael.
how long Danny is available to visit with the speaker.
how long Michael has been in therapy.
how much longer Danny will be in graduate school.

When the speaker asks Danny, ÒHow much time do you have?Ó (line 69), he is referring to:
Danny looks fatigued, as the speaker had expected.
The speaker is surprised by how exhausted Danny looks.
The speaker is amazed that Danny appears well-rested, even though he claims to be tired.
The speaker is relieved that Danny looks much healthier than he did the last time they met.

PROSE FICTION:ÊThis passage is excerpted fromÊThe Promise(1969) by Chaim Potok.

50 absolute lies.ÊHe won't cooperate at all."Ê"Are you taking over the therapy?"Ê"Yes.ÊThey're willing to try almostÊanything now.ÊIt's very serious withÊMichael."
55 I found I could not stop thinkingÊabout Michael.ÊThere was the lake againÊand Michael's thin body near the centerÊboard of the sailfish and the gusting windsÊand the clouds scudding smoothly across the
60 sky.Ê"There have been fist fights.ÊBetween Michael and some of the otherÊboys."Ê"Fist fights," I said.ÊI could not
65 imagine Michael in a fist fight.Ê"He kicked a boy in the groin.ÊDuring a lunch hour.ÊHe pushed him out ofÊthe chair and kicked him".Ê"How much time do you have?"
70 "A month.ÊTwo months.ÊIt dependsÊon whether there's any kind of progress".Ê"What if there's no progress,ÊDanny?"ÊHe glanced down at his desk and
75 said nothing.Ê"Will he have to beÊinstitutionalized?"ÊI said.ÊHe did not say anything.Ê"My God," I said.Ê"My God....All
80 because of a stupid carnival."ÊHe looked at me.Ê"Michael was sickÊlong before that carnival.ÊCrooks atÊcarnivals don't make people sick.ÊYou haveÊto be sick already to be affected that way.
85 "We had a beautiful time on thatÊlake.ÊHe liked to read clouds.ÊDid I tell youÊabout that?ÊHe reads clouds."Ê"You told me."ÊI finished the coffee.Ê"The summer
90 seems very far away."ÊHe was quiet.Ê"It is far away," I said.ÊI put theÊempty coffee cup on the floor and leanedÊback against the wall and closed my eyes.ÊI
95 could not stop thinking aboutÊMichael....There was the cove and theÊsmooth shallow water with the tall trees ofÊthe shoreline breaking the force of the windÊand Michael lying on his back reading the
100 clouds.ÊThere was the cove and the birdsÊÊhigh overhead and the clouds white againstÊÊthe deep blue of the sky and the whisper ofÊÊthe wind through the trees, a loudÊÊwhisper...and I saw Michael standing up in
105 the roller coaster, his face to the wind...andÊÊthe sensation of dropping into the night.

Which of the following best describes the speakerÕs impression of Danny when the speaker first sees him?
the fact that the speaker is talking too loudly to hear anything that Danny says.
the speakerÕs ignorance of the details regarding MichaelÕs condition.
the speakerÕs sarcasm in the previous line.

It was cold and an icy wind that blewalong Broadway and up through the narrowside street where Danny lived, a fierce windthat came off the river, which I could not see
5 for the darkness. The house was small, threestories, red brick, and old, very old. Fiveworn, stone stairs, a badly fitting woodendoor, a tiny overheated foyer withmailboxes, buttons, and nameplates.ÊI
10 pressed the button over the name Saunders.ÊThere was a loud answering buzz.ÊI pushedÊopen the heavy inner door and started up theÊsteep, carpeted, narrow staircase.ÊThe doorÊclosed with a loud click.ÊIt was a little

20 doorway.ÊHe had on a dark woolen sweaterÊand dark trousers.ÊThere was a skullcap onÊhis head.ÊHis face was pale and he blinkedÊat me wearily from behind his black shell-Êrimmed glasses.
